entry.title: HA/DR Architecture on SAP Shared File system on Windows in Azure Cloud
entry.content:
Introduction: This blog explains a reference architecture of a High available SAP system in Windows in Azure Cloud  with DR solution. This is one of the recommended architectures from Microsoft & SAP in Windows in Azure cloud where we will be utilizing Windows DFS-N to support flexible SAP shared file systems.

We will be referring shared file system as below, but same architecture can also be followed in case we have any other shared file system (e.g Interfaces which we would like to have in both regions):

  1. \\<ANF or AFS name >\sapmnt

  2. \\<ANF or AFS name >\trans


Scenario: We can refer this in below scenario:

  • Implementation of SAP systems in High available scenario

  • Configuring SAP Disaster Recovery Solution

  • Operating System will be Windows

  • Azure Site Recovery (ASR) is used for creating Application VMs in DR Region


Benefits:

  • Significant reduction of RTO during Disaster

  • Controlling number of characters on hostname which has limitations (Refer SAP NOTE: 611361,2718300)


Motivation:  

Here is a high level architecture (See Fig 1):

  • ASCS, ERS, PAS and AS are part of Application Subnet which will access their sapmnt or trans directory configured in AFS or ANF which is accessible in that region.

  • AFS or ANF has been provisioned with their physical name as result of that all the profiles, registry, Configtools parameters, interfaces will point to that physical name.

  • Database subnets are not shown below as they used local FS ( e.g /hana/data, /hana/log) and async mode replication is configured between primary and secondary region.



                                                         Fig 1

Now during Disaster, as per recommendation from Microsoft Azure, ASR will be used to provision VMs in secondary DR region as below (Check Fig 2):


                                                          Fig 2

Now, here it comes the difficulties as with ASR , all details of registry values, profiles, configtool  parameters of region1 has come to region2. Basis team will need significant amount of time to change this and aligned as per Region2. Also when we need to fail back again to Region1, that time also we need to change those details as per Region1.

Hence, instead of using direct AFS or ANF physical name its strongly advised to use windows DFS-N which will support the naming convention of all these File shares(Check Fig 3).

                                                                   Fig 3


And During Disaster, here is what can be achieved as target architecture ( Fig4):


                                                 Fig 4

With this, we can achieve significant reduction of RTO and completely reduce entire steps of changing registry values, profiles or configtool parameters which will help Basis team. During failback to Region1 also, same can be followed without any manual intervention.

NOTE: We still need to perform few parameters changes ( e.g ASCS, DB load balancers in default profiles).

High Level Technical Steps:

Here is the high level steps I tried to update :

  • Install and Configure DFS-N for /sapmnt and /trans shared FS which should point as per above diagram( Please refer : https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows-server/storage/dfs-namespaces/dfs-overview)

  • Make sure newly DFS are pointing correctly from all the Azure Application Subnet VMs.

  • Install SAP HA system with File share Cluster mentioning DFS-N names.

  • Check window registry , profile parameters. Now all should point to DFS-N names and should not point to any physical AFS/ANF names.


NOTE: In case , SAP is already installed and we need to change from physical name to DFS-N names , then we need to change registry , profiles and configtool parameters manually which will be one time activity.

entry.title: Simplification List for Plant Maintenance (Enterprise Asset Management)
entry.content:
Introduction:


While delivering SAP S/4HANA on-premise services at customer site or when I meet any consultant from the implementation partner company, the first question I get is the list of pre-requisites to be handled before SAP S/4HANA transition with respect to Enterprise Asset Management (formerly Plant Maintenance. Henceforth it will be termed as EAM  in this blog) application. This happened many times & still I am getting this question. So, I thought of writing a blog which helps customers, partners, consultants, users & other stake holders with this frequently asked questions.

Simplification List/Items (SI checks):


Simplification list provides detailed functional-level descriptions of the required changes to individual transactions and solution capabilities in SAP S/4HANA. It supports customers who are converting from SAP ECC/on-premise edition to SAP S/4HANA. The Simplification List provides information on the activities customers need to complete before, during, and after the conversion to SAP S/4HANA.

This list is prepared during “prepare phase” of the transition. The list is available in the system using the TA: /SDF/RC_START_CHECK.  These pre-checks will check the usage of the existing SAP Business Suite system during the planning phase prior to the actual conversion to SAP S/4HANA, identify the relevant Simplification Items.

Different actions/steps have to be taken for different applications for the smooth SAP S/4HANA transition. SAP provides SAP S/4HANA Transition Worklist item ( which I will refer here in this blog as S4TWL ) NOTES for each item.

 

Transition phases to SAP S/4HANA:

 

SAP S/4HANA Transition Phases


 

 

Prepare Phase


The Simplification List, therefore, serves three purposes:

    • Planning the actual system conversion from a traditional ERP solution to SAP S/4HANA.

 

    • Reducing efforts during the actual conversion by taking necessary steps/actions for each simplification items in advance.

 

    • Avoids re-work by implementing SAP S/4HANA-compliant strategic capabilities (when rolling out new capabilities).



Note:

    • All the items mentioned below may not be valid for all the customers. Run the TA: /SDF/RC_START_CHECK to know the items which are valid for you.

 

    • Following simplification is valid as of SAP S/4HANA 2022. New items may be added in future.

 

    • Impact & validity of each simplification items will vary across different customers.



 

Simplification List for the EAM Application:

 

Overall list & comments:

 

SL #TitleSAP Note #Result
1S4TWL - Object List Number Field Length Extension2580670Increase in the DDIC length.
SUM tool will take care of this automatically.
2S4TWL - LIS in EAM2267463Future PM analytics will be based on HANA & CDS views.
User can still access the classic LIS.
3S4TWL - Download Data in MS Access out of List2270076Use MS Excel instead of MS Access DB.
4S4TWL - Scheduling of Maintenance Plan2270078TA: IP30 & its report RISTRA20 still exists in SAP S/4HANA system. User can evaluate new TA:  IP30H & its new report RISTRA20H for reference.
5S4TWL - Batch Input for Enterprise Asset Management (EAM)2270107TA IBIP is not support further.
Use corresponding BAPI’s.
6S4TWL - Changes In List Reports For Order and Notification2270108TA: IW37 & IW49 exists in SAP S/4HANA system.
User can evaluate & use the new TA: IW37N & IW49N.
7S4TWL - WebDynpro Application for Maintenance Planner (<= EhP4)2270110Use the new Maintenance Planner and Maintenance Worker Roles instead of maintenance technician role.
8S4TWL - Enterprise Search in EAM2270123The way the search is performed is changed. No action is required.
9S4TWL - SAP Graphics in EAM Transactions2482659Tabular or other formats display exists & no graphical display.
10S4TWL - Mobile Asset Management (MAM)2270080Use "asset manager" instead of MAM.
11S4TWL - Obsolete POWL Applications3372889 Few fiori apps are marked as deprecated & obsolete. New alternative apps are provided.  


 

Details of each item:




    1. S4TWL - Object List Number Field Length Extension



Note# 2580670

SAP has decided to extend the object list numbers (data element OBJKNR, domain OBJKN) from the data format INT4 to the data format INT8. This change affects all the tables (e.g: OBJK) that contain a field with a reference to the data element OBJKNR.

 



OBJK table in ECC System


 


OBJK table in SAP S/4HANA System


Required actions:

    • Its information only.

 

    • SUM will take care of it automatically.



 

2. S4TWL - LIS in EAM


Note# 2267463

Its an information only item where future analytical reports, transactions are based on HANA & CDS which simplifies the process by reducing the tables & improves the performance.

Required actions:

    • Enhancements and modifications of the LIS will not work for the future analytic solution.

 

    • Custom report will stop working after update which are accessing the tables S061 to S065, S070, S114 to S116.



 

3. S4TWL - Download Data in MS Access out of List


Note# 2270076

SAP GUI supports downloading data to MS Access. This functionality is not the target architecture. Though, this functionality is available in SAP S/4HANA on-premises but not considered as future technology.

 

 

Notification to MS Access DB


 

 

DB Details for storing Notification data


Required actions:

    • Stop downloading data to MS access.

 

    • Use download to Excel or Open Office. Within Excel / Open Office you can use the embedded tools for populating to DB.




    1.  



4. S4TWL - Scheduling of Maintenance Plan


Note# 2270078

Maintenance scheduling transaction IP30 (Reports RISTRA20) uses the outdated technology & it is still available in SAP S/4HANA system but not considered for future. This transaction is replaced by new transaction & report -- IP30H & RISTRA20H.



TA: IP30H in SAP S/4HANA System


 

Required actions:

Check for the scheduled background jobs (SM37) with the old report RISTRA20. Delete those jobs & replace them with the new report (RISTRA20H).

 

5. S4TWL - Batch Input for Enterprise Asset Management (EAM)


Note# 2270107

Transaction IBIP uses Batch Input (outdated) technology to create transactional data for EAM objects. This is still available in SAP S/4HANA system but not considered for future.

 

TA: IBIP in both ECC and SAP S/4HANA systems


Required actions:

Plant maintenance offers lot of BAPI’s (mentioned in the note 2270107) to create transaction data. Create custom programs using these API’s to create EAM object data in the system instead of TA: IBIP.

 

6. S4TWL - Changes In List Reports For Order and Notification


Note# 2270108

Transactions IW37 & IW49 are w.r.t order operations are improved further (performance) in new TA: IW37n & IW49n. Though the existing TA’s IW37 & IW49 are available in the SAP S/4HANA system but are not considered for future.

 

TA: IW37N and IW49N


Required Actions:

    • run the reports 'QM_PHASE_FILL' and 'RIAFVC_IPHAS_FILL' before the upgrade to SAP S/4HANA.

 

    • start using the new TA: IW37n & IW49n instead of IW37 & IW49.



 

7. S4TWL - WebDynpro Application for Maintenance Planner (<= EhP4)


Note# 2270110

Maintenance Technician role is obsolete for SAP S/4HANA release. Though it is still available in SAP S/4HANA but not in future.

Use the new Maintenance Planner and Maintenance Worker Roles available in SAP S/4HANA.

Required Actions:

Activate the Business Functions (LOG_EAM_SIMPLICITY_2 to 6) in TA: SFW5 to get the full functionality of Maintenance Planner and Maintenance Worker Role.

 

SFW5 in ECC System


 

 

SFW5 in SAP S/4HANA System


 

8. S4TWL - Enterprise Search in EAM


Note# 2270123

With SAP S/4HANA, on-premise edition, the Enterprise Search models are now replication free search models using HDB. This means reliance on TREX & other replication data processes are eliminated. Now, the searches are based on SAP S/4HANA DB tables directly.

Required Actions:

Check the note 2270123 to follow the mentioned steps to activate the search models or if you are intending to use value help within WebDynpro App.

 

Enterprise Search in S/4 HANA



9. S4TWL - SAP Graphics in EAM Transactions


Note# 2482659

SAP Business Graphics used in Plant Maintenance applications are no longer supported in SAP S/4HANA. Example of affected TA: IP19.

 

TA: IP19 in ECC


 

 

TA: IP19 in SAP S/4HANA


Other affected transactions are available as the PDF attachment in the NOTE.

Required Actions:

Use the tabular display.

 

10. S4TWL - Mobile Asset Management (MAM)


Note# 2270080

The 'Mobile Asset Management' solution is not supported in S/4HANA. User can use the fiori apps on mobile or use “asset manager” (additional license required).

11. S4TWL - Obsolete POWL Applications in Maintenance Management

Note# 3372889 

Few Personal Object Worklist (POWL, based on WebDynpro) fiori apps have been deprecated in SAP S/4HANA 2022 and are obsolete since 2023. These apps are not available in fiori launchpad henceforth. 

Kindly check the note for list of identified apps & its corresponding successor apps. 


 

Additional Information:


Simplification items check:

    • can be run manually in advance on the actual SAP ERP system.

 

    • It is necessary to resolve all "red" inconsistency checks, otherwise the system conversion will fail.

 

    • will be run by the Software Update Manager (SUM) at least twice during the conversion procedure



Next Steps:


This blog detailed out the list of EAM items which are changed or deleted in SAP S/4HANA product compared to Ehp/ECC product & consultants are required to demo these changes to stake holders before SAP S/4HANA transition so that their daily work is not affected by these changes.

Overall, I have shared the contents with respect to all the EAM simplification items which are valid till SAP S/4HANA 2022.

entry.title: Plan Your Conversion to SAP S/4HANA – Expert Guided Implementation
entry.content:
Is your organization planning to take the next big digital move from SAP ERP to SAP S/4HANA or SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Private Edition? Are you wondering where to start and curious about what’s involved in this journey? You are in the right place!

Transforming your digital business core from SAP ERP to SAP S/4HANA could be complex but rewarding - so is the process of planning such a project. Planning an SAP S/4HANA conversion project involves various tools, teams, and expertise for a smooth and successful Go-Live. This is where SAP Enterprise Support Academy helps you in being informed of all the tools, technologies, and techniques you need to consume and apply along different phases of the project.

The EGI “Plan Your Conversion to SAP S/4HANA” covers a range of topics that are key to planning your SAP S/4HANA conversion project. The session answers topics like how SAP S/4HANA is better and different from SAP ERP, discusses the different editions of SAP S/4HANA and how to plan and successfully execute the transition to SAP S/4HANA. This session also highlights the starting points and best practices for the conversion.

What is an Expert Guided Implementation? 


An expert-guided implementation (EGI) is a remote training session delivered virtually over several days. For further details on the EGI format and a list of the SAP S/4HANA related expert-guided implementation training sessions, see the blog: Expert-Guided Implementation (EGI) – The practical training option

When should I attend this Expert Guided Implementation? 


Customers usually attend this EGI during the Discover phase of their SAP S/4HANA conversion project. From the session, you will know how the data model of SAP S/4HANA is simplified and better suited for running your business processes simpler and faster. We will also discuss about SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud and On-Premise deployment options and what “RISE with SAP” has to offer. You will be equipped with all the essential planning elements of your conversion project by the end of this EGI.

* Before you can access the registration links, a one-time registration in SAP Learning Hub, edition for SAP Enterprise Support, is required. A detailed step-by step guide to registration can be found  here

What topics will be covered in this EGI?


A summary of the contents is listed below. For the full schedule see the abstract listed here

Plan Your Conversion to SAP S/4HANA*


Day 1 Major Topics



  • SAP S/4HANA introduction

  • Transition scenarios to SAP S/4HANA

  • Key activities and planning elements of an SAP S/4HANA conversion project


Day 2 Major Topics



  • SAP Readiness Check for SAP S/4HANA

  • Simplification Items Check

  • Functional Preparations – Finance, Customers and Vendors


Day 3 Major Topics



  • SAP Maintenance Planner

  • Custom code activities in SAP S/4HANA Conversion Projects

  • Recommended activities for SAP Fiori and SAP S/4HANA Embedded Analytics

  • Software Update Manager (SUM) and DMO Option of SUM

  • Downtime Minimization Approaches

  • SAP HANA 2

  • Target System Sizing


What are the key benefits of attending this EGI? 


This EGI is power packed with a lot of essential information and knowledge pointers that you need right from the start of the project until the Go-Live on SAP S/4HANA. Attending this EGI will also reduce the time required to upskill for planning an SAP S/4HANA Conversion project.  At the end of the EGI, you will be empowered with the approaches and techniques you need to apply to efficiently convert your SAP ERP systems to SAP S/4HANA. entry.title: Near-Zero Downtime Maintenance for High Availability / Disaster Recovery (HA/DR) SAP Java Systems
entry.content:
Overview

Being up-to-date with the latest technologies and aiming the production stability and consistency are the top priorities for most businesses. However, that often requires business critical downtime for production systems. SAP offers a solution to this problem by providing its clients with the near-Zero Downtime Maintenance (nZDM) for SAP Java procedure for its SAP Java systems.

This blog gives an overview of the nZDM Java solution and the specifics of performing it on High Availability / Disaster Recovery (HA/DR) SAP Java systems.

 

What is the nZDM Java procedure?

The near-Zero Downtime Maintenance for SAP Java is a procedure that enables you to perform maintenance activities with greatly reduced business downtime on SAP Portal, SAP Process Orchestration (PO) and SAP systems that have only some of the usage types part of SAP Process Orchestration. nZDM Java deliveries are part of SAP SL Toolset program.

The nZDM Java procedure allows SAP customers to perform all maintenance activities on a copy or clone of the system (also called ‘target system’ in the context of nZDM) while the production system (called ‘source system’) is still in use.

More information about the nZDM solution can be found here:

nZDM Java: minimize the business downtime of your SAP Process Orchestration maintenance activity

 

Approaches for performing nZDM Java

Depending on the client’s system landscape and complexity, there are two main approaches for performing nZDM Java. Both rely on the copy or clone of the production system and include some basic common steps but the finalization steps differ.

Below the different approaches are explained via diagrams. The following legend describes the meaning of the different colors:


 

  • System switch


This approach is suitable for virtualized systems as well as HA/DR systems. The system’s clone will become the new production system. Before replacing the production system with the target system, testing the updated clone is possible without downtime. This happens in a special ‘nZDM test mode’.

The technical downtime is approximately the time needed to restart the system. It varies depending on the type and load of the system.

These are the generic steps of performing a ‘System Switch’ on a standard Process Orchestration system:

 

0. Initial State

The system on which we perform the ‘System Switch’ is a SAP Process Orchestration (PO) system consisting of several components: one or more Java Application Servers (AS), SAP Web Dispatcher (WD), SAP Central Services (SCS), SAP Enqueue Replication Service (ERS) and a database.


 

1. Preparation

Prepare the production system for nZDM Java: configure database settings, deactivate background jobs, set the landscape directory (SLD) to read-only mode, download and run the nZDM Java GUI on a separate host.

 

2. Connect the nZDM Java GUI to the source (production) system

Connect the nZDM Java GUI to one of the application servers of the source system.



 

3. Start recording

Initialize recording of the database changes on the production system.


 

4. Clone the source (production) system

Clone the source (production) system to create a target system.



 

5. Isolate the cloned system

Configure the isolation (network fencing) of the target system to avoid conflict with the source (production) system.

 

6. Start the target system

When the isolated clone is started, it starts as a target system.



 

7. Update the target system

Perform the desired maintenance activities on the target system.



 

8. (optional) Test the updated system

The updated target system can be tested before replacing the production system. No production system downtime is required for while testing on the target system. However, before performing tests it is important to do a backup of the target system. After the tests, the target system is restored to that backup.


 

9. Connect nZDM Java GUI to the target system



 

10. Start DB data replication from the source system to the target system

Replicate all available data changes from the source’s DB to the target system.



 

11. Stop source system / enter downtime phase

To replicate the last data changes the source system is stopped, starting the downtime phase. Only the DB of the source system remains active so that the replication can be finished.

This phase is activated via the nZDM GUI.



 

12. Stop and unfence target system

After finishing the replication, the updated target system is stopped and unfenced. Once unfenced, it can be started.

 

13. Start updated system / end of downtime phase

After starting the updated system, it replaces the original and becomes the new production system.



 

  • Database switch


Recommended when there is no virtualization of the system and not suitable for High Availability / Disaster Recovery systems. It uses the newly created database on the existing source system DB host. The data is cloned on the existing database server or on a shared storage. This approach is useful when the existing productive environment has a large scale and complex configurations. Therefore it might be the least costly way to use the already existing environment.

 

nZDM Java on High Availability / Disaster Recovery (HA/DR) SAP Java System

Depending on the scenario and the suitable approach for it, the steps of the nZDM Java procedure may differ. This section contains a step-by-step description of a successfully performed scenario of nZDM Java on HA/DR systems.

 

nZDM Java on HA/DR System: Cluster Clone

This approach for nZDM Java on HA/DR system is more suitable for virtualized systems or other environments where making a clone or a copy of the system can be easily performed. With the HA/DR ‘Cluster Clone’ the update is performed on a clone / copy of the production system. During the maintenance performed on of the clone (target system), the production system (source system) is active. The downtime is required for completion of the replication of data changes from source to target and takes about one system restart time.

These are the generic steps of performing a ‘Cluster Clone’ on a two-node HA/DR system setup:

 

0. Initial State

The system on which we perform the ‘Cluster Clone’ is a HA/DR SAP Java system with two nodes and multiple application servers. Each node may have SAP Web Dispatcher (WD), SAP Central Services (SCS), SAP Enqueue Replication Service (ERS) and a database. The nodes are bound together in a HA/DR cluster via HA/DR software.

There is only one active WD, SCS, ERS and DB instance in the cluster of nodes at any given moment. If an active instance fails, the inactive activates and replaces it.



 

1. Preparation

Prepare the production system for nZDM Java: configure database settings, deactivate background jobs, set the landscape directory (SLD) to read-only mode, download and run the nZDM Java GUI on a separate host.

 

2. Connect nZDM Java GUI to the source (production) system

Connect the nZDM Java GUI to one of the application servers of the source system.



 

3. Start recording

Initialize recording of the database changes on the production system.

 

4. Clone the source (production) system

Clone the whole cluster of nodes to create a target system.



 

5. Isolate the cloned system

Configure the isolation (network fencing) of the target system to avoid conflict with the source (production) system.

 

6. Start the target system

When the isolated clone is started, it becomes our target system.



 

7. Update the target system

Perform the desired maintenance activities on the target system.



 

8. (optional) Test the updated system

The updated target system can be tested before replacing the production system. No production system downtime is required for while testing on the target system. However, before performing tests it is important to do a backup of the target system. After the tests, the target system is restored to that backup.

 

9. Connect nZDM Java GUI to the target system



 

10. Start DB data replication from the source system to the target system

Begin replication of data changes from the source’s DB to the target system.



 

11. Stop source system / enter downtime phase

To replicate the last data changes the source system is stopped, starting the downtime phase. Only the DB of the source system remains active so that the replication can be finished.

This phase is activated via the nZDM GUI.



 

12. Stop and unfence target system

After finishing the replication, the updated target system is stopped and unfenced. Once unfenced, it can be started.

 

13. Start updated system / end of downtime phase

After starting the updated system, it replaces the original and becomes the new production system.



 

Conclusion

The nZDM Java procedure offers a flexible and effective solution for updating SAP Java systems. It also supports various High Availability / Disaster Recovery landscapes of SAP Java systems. The main benefits of the procedure are the significantly reduced downtime and the ability to test the updated system before making it a production system, minimizing the risk of possible problems.

 

Further Information

nZDM Java user guides and the nZDM Java GUI are available at http://service.sap.com/sltoolset

Minimizing planned downtime during maintenance

entry.title: Two Major News with SUM 2.0 SP 17
entry.content:
Hello SUM fans, this blog is a bit long and full of text, but it's worth reading, as we have great news!

1. Homogeneous option for DMO


SUM 2.0 SP 17 (available as of May 26th 2023) offers a homogeneous option for DMO!

Until now, DMO was always heterogenous: the database type was always changed, for example from DB2 to SAP HANA DB. Now, for the first time, SUM allows a homogeneous migration from SAP HANA DB to SAP HANA DB.

But this comes only for specific cases:

    • Only SAP HANA DB to SAP HANA DB is supported
      (no plan to offer homogeneous DMO for other database types)
    • Only target product SAP S/4HANA is supported
      (target "SAP ERP on SAP HANA" is not supported)
    • Some restrictions apply for schemas and partitioning
      (documented in SAP Note 3296427 on DMO)
    • doDMO and doC are not (yet) supported for homogeneous DMO
      (plan is to support this with a later SUM SP version, maybe SP 18 in October, or later)
      (with SUM 2.0 SP 17, we accept pilot projects for homogenous DMO with doDMO or with doC)

 

1.1. Main Use Case


So, "DMO with system move" allows SAP HANA to SAP HANA migration. The main scenario that benefits from this new feature is the combined conversion & transition:
convert "SAP ERP on SAP HANA DB" to SAP S/4HANA and transition the system to SAP S/4HANA Cloud, private edition (or any hyperscaler) in one step.

Up to now, this was a 2-step approach:


Now, it is a 1-step procedure:


(The illustrations are based on the PCE documentation: Transition Paths | SAP Help Portal)

1.2. Further use case


Another scenario that benefits from this new feature is the transition of an existing SAP S/4HANA (on-prem) system to SAP S/4HANA Cloud, private edition.




    • Either upgrading to higher SAP S/4HANA release
    • Or keeping source product version level, combining it with „DMO without system update“

        • For this, backup/restore or HANA tenant copy is probably the easier approach

        • Keep in mind that with any DMO scenario, the System-ID of the source system will generally be kept


1.3. Minor further use case


The option can also be used purely on-premise for a change of the SAP HANA database during a conversion from SAP ERP on SAP HANA DB to SAP S/4HANA. Like starting SAP ERP on SAP HANA 1.0 and omitting the separate SAP HANA upgrade to SAP HANA 2.0.

1.4. Overview on new scenarios for "DMO with system move"

 


The illustration shows the main use case in the middle, the further use case above, and the minor further use case left hand side with a dotted line. All three cases are listed in orange. The thin blue lines on bottom indicate the already existing use case for "DMO with system move" from non -  SAP HANA DB on source.

1.5. Further information

 

    • SAP Note 3296427 for DMO with SUM 2.0 SP 17
      (sections on "Homogeneous database migration")
    • DMO Guide for SUM 2.0 SP 17
      (sections on "Homogeneous database migration")

 

2. DMOVE2S4: "DMO move to SAP S/4HANA (on hyperscaler)"

 

2.1. Alternative to "DMO with system move"


For the combined conversion & transition, until now only "DMO with system move" was available and used for projects. Disadvantage is that the approach does not allow downtime-optimization techniques like downtime-optimized DMO (doDMO) or downtime-optimized Conversion. Now with SUM 2.0 SP 17, the DMOVE2S4 approach is available as an alternative to "DMO with system move" - under specific conditions (described below). It allows to use the plain-DMO (plain in the sense of "not-DMO-with-system-move") for the conversion and transition to a hyperscaler.

Note: you may have heard about this approach already, but with other names: "DMO to Azure", or "DMO conversion to hyperscaler".

2.2. Advantages

 

    • Proven SUM technology is used
      (not brand new coding)
    • Approach works for source systems on anyDB as well as on SAP HANA DB
      because SUM now allows homogeneous migration (SAP HANA DB to SAP HANA DB, see section 1 above)
    • DMOVE2S4 can be used as is, or additionally with downtime-optimization techniques
      like doDMO, or doC (but currently only if source is on non-SAP HANA DB, see section 1 above)
    • R3load pipe mode is used, not file mode
      so no dump files are created like for "DMO with system move"


So the approach comes with three potential usages / flavors:

    • DMOVE2S4 (plain)
      DMOVE2S4 with downtime-optimized DMO
      DMOVE2S4 with downtime-optimized Conversion

 

2.3. Main steps of approach




    1. Install AAS in target
      In the target environment, in which the target SAP HANA DB is installed, you install an Additional Application Server (AAS) which belongs to the source SAP ERP 6.0.
    2. Extract and start SUM on that AAS
      You start SUM for the conversion on that AAS host in the target environment.
    3. You confirm the "ACSC instance move" offered by SUM
      As SUM detects that it is not running on the Primary Application Server (PAS) host, it offers the ASCS instance move. This will install the ABAP central services on the AAS in the target, and the previous PAS will not be started again after downtime.
    4. Post-activities
      Some post activities are required which are described in the DMO Guide, like moving the directories sapmnt and trans to the hyperscaler.

Although it is not listed here, it is important to enable the required communication between the source and target environment, like opening ports.
The whitepaper "Converting from SAP ERP on Premise to SAP S/4HANA on Microsoft Azure" (listed below) explains those steps in detail, for the case of target hyperscaler MS Azure.

Note that the "ASCS instance move" will move the ASCS instance to a host on which an AAS is running. If the source system had the ASCS running separately from any Application Server Instances, this setup will not be restored by SUM (see blog post  https://blogs.sap.com/2019/04/12/ascs-instance-move-use-sum-to-switch-your-ascs/). It is of course possible to afterwards manually create such a setup. In case of a transition to "SAP S/4HANA Cloud, private edition", the AAS is anyhow installed (by the executing partner) on the "migration server" which is provided by SAP (ECS). After the partner has finished the conversion run, the migration server will anyhow be dismantled.

 

Note on point 1: Install AAS in target [added on June 16 2023]
The OS of the AAS host has to be supported, e.g. for MS SQL database, it must run on Windows. You should check if the target environment supports that OS.

Note on point 3: Confirm "ASCS instance move" [added on July 6 2023]
If your ASCS instance is not yet running separately on your source system, SUM will automatically execute the "ASCS instance split" (see SUM guide: ASCS Instance Split | SAP Help Portal). The new ASCS instance will then be created on the AAS.

2.4. Approach is not a SUM option


Note that the DMOVE2S4 approach is the appropriate combination of SUM features and option, but it is not an option which is offered by SUM. The SUM is not aware if it is used for the approach, and will not show this for example in the title of the browser window. This is different to "DMO with system move" which is a SUM option, and which is shown on the SUM browser page.

2.5. Prerequisites and conditions



    • DMOVE2S4 is only supported for target SAP S/4HANA
    • It is supported if the technical requirements are met (actual values are listed in SAP Note 3296427 on DMO with SUM 2.0 SP 17)

        • Latency < 20 ms

        • Bandwidth > 400 MBit/s



Note: SUM runs a latency check (result is visible in DBSTAT.LOG file). For higher latency values, a warning is shown in log file CHECKS.log. The latency check is executed for conversion with migration and for an SUM "extended prerequisite check" (with target database).

2.6. Further information



    • DMO Guide: DMO Move to SAP S/4HANA (on Hyperscaler) | SAP Help Portal
    • SAP Note 3296427 for DMO with SUM 2.0 SP 17
      (sections on "DMO Move to SAP S/4HANA")
    • White paper: "Converting from SAP ERP on Premise to SAP S/4HANA on Microsoft Azure":
      https://www.sap.com/documents/2021/12/a8fcb608-097e-0010-bca6-c68f7e60039b.html
    • Initial blog post in SAP Community: “DMO to Azure”: combine SAP S/4HANA conversion with the move to Azure (without “DMO with System Move”) | SAP Blogs



2.7. Illustration


The illustration shows both options for a combined conversion & transition.
Note that DMOVE2S4 requires target product SAP S/4HANA, different to "DMO with system move".


So if two options are available, which one to chose?

    • First question is whether the latency and the bandwidth are good enough for DMOVE2S4. If not, then "DMO with system move" is to be used.

        • Only if conditions are met to use DMOVE2S4, then the second question is:
          is downtime optimization required? If yes, then DMOVE2S4 is the right choice.


Boris Rubarth
Product Management SUM, SAP SE

entry.title: Free Learning Journey That Qualifies You to Use Zero Downtime Option (ZDO) in SUM for SAP S/4HANA Updates
entry.content:
Many blog posts have been released over the past years explaining the Zero Downtime Option (ZDO) in Software Update Manager (SUM) and how it ensures performing maintenance events without technical downtime. As of SAP S/4HANA 2021 release and with SUM 2.0 SP12, you can make use of Zero Downtime Option for SAP S/4HANA. In this blog, I want to introduce you to the free and self-paced learning journey Leverage SAP S/4HANA Updates and Upgrades with Zero Downtime Option of SUM on learning.sap.com. This self-paced and interactive learning journey provides you with all necessary information that is needed to operate SUM with ZDO, plan, and execute maintenance projects. When you choose in SUM the Scenario Strategy Zero Downtime Option (ZDO), you will be prompted for an authentication. Part of it is to successfully complete this learning journey.

ZDO decreases the downtime significantly. With the option, technical unavailability of a system can be reduced to a single restart of application servers. This is possible due to the temporary transition to a bridge subsystem. In the meantime, the maintenance is performed on the original system. After the restart of the application servers, there is a switch back and the original system is available in the new release. Since ZDO is part of the SUM tool, it does not require any additional license. You need, however, to ensure that a minimal additional space in the database is available.

The learning journey consists of five units, is 9h long, and describes what you as technical consultant or system administrator need to know. You will learn:

  • how ZDO is performed

  • what do you need to prepare

  • what are the different components in a maintenance project, like original system, bridge subsystem, database, releases

  • and what other options are there in SUM


One of the units explains the supporting tools, prerequisites and restrictions when using ZDO of SUM for SAP S/4HANA. Backup plan and recovery strategy are also important aspects of a maintenance event. The learning journey highlights how the strategy should be with ZDO.

At the end, you will get an overview of all important resources in one place: SAP Notes, which need to be implemented before and while the maintenance event, where to implement them, and guides describing the execution of the maintenance event in SUM:

  • What steps are required for a successful execution?

  • How to analyze errors and troubleshoot if something goes wrong?

  • What will be the impact on the business process and how to analyze it?


After completing the learning journey, you will get a record of achievement, which is a digital badge on the Credly platform. Only after receiving this badge, you will be able to request a password for SUM when you choose the Scenario Strategy Zero Downtime Option (ZDO).

Fill the gap through upskilling and enjoy SAP’s learning offerings on the SAP Learning site. This article is created and brought to you by SAP Product Learning CoE experts!

entry.title: Keeping SAP System Landscape Secure and Up-to-Date With SAP Notes Recommendations in Maintenance Planner
entry.content:
Introduction


Your SAP system landscape requires regular maintenance, updates, and security checks to ensure optimal performance and compliance. SAP Notes are delivered to address issues related to functionality, performance, security and compliance with legal changes to ensure optimal functioning and security of SAP systems.

In this blog post, we will explore the latest enhancement to Maintenance Planner - the View Recommended Notes feature. Let's explore its key features and how it helps administrators keep SAP systems up-to-date. With View Recommended Notes feature, you can view the SAP Notes that are recommended for your ABAP and JAVA systems in your landscapes. These recommendations provide a detailed list of SAP Notes which should be implemented based on the actual status of your systems and already implemented SAP Notes.

Key Features:

  • Allows filtering of list of systems using landscapes and other filters to identify and calculate SAP Notes accordingly.

  • Allows filtering of list of  SAP Notes based on Security Notes, Hot News, Performance Notes, and Legal Changes.

  • Displays SAP Notes and its link to view its details and implementation prerequisites.

  • Detailed information on SAP Notes and the software components where it is applicable.

  • Logs show actions performed on SAP Notes including user ID, processing status, date, time, and comments.


Using View Recommended Notes, you can also manage the recommended SAP Notes by changing their processing status. This will help you in segregating which SAP Notes you want to implement. Once an SAP Note is completely implemented and has been registered by the LMDB, you can no longer see them in the application.

Calculating the Recommended SAP Notes


To calculate and view the recommended Notes for the selected systems, follow the below steps:

  1. Choose View Recommended Notes tile from the home page.

  2. Select the systems for which you want to view the Notes and click Calculate Notes.


 

A list of all the recommended SAP Notes for the selected systems is displayed.


To get more information on the Note, click the SAP Note number. The right panel displays Note details and the system to which it is applicable. It also displays the category, priority, component, CVSS score for security Notes, and logs of the actions performed on the Note.


You can filter the list of recommended Notes using the following options:

  • Results - Displays all the recommended Notes with their total count for the selected systems.

  • SAP Security Notes - Displays notes specific to security and protection of the systems.
    Note: You need to have 'Security Contact' authorization to access security Notes of any system. For authorization, search and contact your administrator from this

  • Hot News - Displays Notes that are of the highest priority.

  • Performance Notes - Displays Notes that are critical for your system's performance.

  • Legal Change Notes - Displays Notes relevant for any legal changes required for your systems.


You can also perform the following actions:

  • Search- Search for a Note from the list using its name or number.

  • Filter- Filter the Notes list based on the displayed columns.

  • Reset Filter- Remove all the applied filters to view all the available Notes in the list.

  • Sort- Sort the list in ascending or descending order based on various properties like system, Note number, category, etc.

  • Group- Group the Notes together in ascending or descending order based on the properties.

  • Settings- Choose the columns that you want to see on the screen accordingly.

  • Export to Excel- Download and save the filtered list of Notes in an excel file format.

  • Edit Processing Status- Change the processing status of the selected Notes.


Processing the Recommended Notes


Maintenance planner not only gives you a way to view these SAP Notes, but you can also manage them using the View Recommended Notes section. It allows you to change the processing status of the Notes based on your requirements.

Pre-requisites


To change the processing status, you need to first enable the Processing Status column in View Recommended Notes. Click Username > Personalize > Notes Recommendation. Select Change Processing Status and click Save.

To change the processing status of the Notes, follow the below steps:

1. From the list of recommended Notes calculated for the selected systems, click the pencil icon displayed in the Processing Status column for the Note whose status you want to change.  2. In the Change Processing Status pop-up, enter the following detailsa. Select Status: Select the appropriate status for the Note from the drop-down list.








      • Transferring - Note is transferred for implementation.

      • In Progress - Note implementation is in progress

      • On Hold - Note is yet to be decided if it needs to be implemented or is irrelevant.

      • Not Relevant - Invalid or irrelevant Note for your system.






b. Comments: Enter additional information related to the Note.


3. Click Save to update the processing status.
Note: To change the processing status of multiple Notes, select the required Notes and click the pencil icon displayed at the right corner of the toolbar. Select the appropriate status from the drop-down list, enter a comment if any, and click Save.


After a Note is implemented on the target system, it's no longer recommended and automatically removed from the list.

Roadmap


For easier implementation of SAP Notes on the applicable systems, we are evaluating a new option to download the recommendations in XML file format. You can then upload the XML file in the Note Assistant tool to experience automated implementation process.

For more information, see FAQs in the SAP Note 3359264.

To add complexity , customers now even look forward to take an opportunity to migrate from On Premise DC to Cloud ~ Hyperscaler under one major transformation program.

entry.title: Simply analyzing and improving maintenance events with Technical Downtime Optimization App
entry.content:
Regular maintenance of the SAP landscape is essential for ensuring that it remains high-performing and offers the latest features. However, maintenance events typically require system downtime, during which production operations are paused until the maintenance is completed.

(It is important to note that downtime doesn't just involve the technical unavailability of the system. It also includes activities such as ramping down the system, ramping it back up and testing, all of which is not productive use, that is business downtime. When I mention downtime in this blog, I’m referring specifically to the technical downtime caused by Software Update Manager.)

SAP provides the Software Update Manager for carrying out maintenance events. To ensure that the maintenance using Software Update Manager on the production system goes smoothly and according to plan, test cycles are performed before updating* production. Typically, the first system to be updated is a sandbox system that is separate from the production landscape. This sandbox system is used to validate the upgrade process and identify any necessary preparation steps and fixes.

Once the sandbox has been successfully updated, the next step is to assess the project planning implications of the update. This involves analyzing the overall maintenance runtime and downtime, ensuring that the downtime fits within the planned maintenance window, and finding ways to potentially shorten the downtime if necessary.

To address these concerns, SAP offer the Technical Downtime Optimization App. This app provides multiple features for analyzing the Software Update Manager runtime and improving the maintenance event.

*Note: Update refers to any maintenance in this text, i.e. release changes (upgrades), Feature or Support Package Stack implementation (update) and import of customer transports.

 

Prerequisites

Software Update Manager offers to send the analysis files of the maintenance event (UPGANA.XML and, in case of system conversion to SAP S/4HANA®, APPLANA.XML) to SAP. Shortly after submission, the event will be visible in the Technical Downtime Optimization app.

Screenshot of Software Update Manager end screen with the feedback window

If the data was not sent by Software Update Manager, the XML files can be uploaded manually in the app.

 

Accessing the Technical Downtime Optimization App

The app is available here: https://tdo.cloud.sap/.

 

Using the Technical Downtime Optimization App

The first step is to choose the event for analysis.

The default view upon entry is the Durations tab, which provides a visual overview of the overall Software Update Manager runtime. The overview shows the overall runtime and offers to drill down into the blocks by clicking on them.

Screenshot of the Durations feature

The Rating feature offers numerical ratings that compare the current run to similar events in the database.  This feature also provides comments and best practice information for improving the rating.

Screenshot of the Rating feature

The Compare feature allows for a comparison between separate runs. For example, two runs with different parametrization can be compared.

Screenshot of the Compare feature comparing two events

Also, more than two events can be compared.

Screenshot of the Compare feature comparing more than two events

To identify potential measures for improving downtime, the Simulate feature offers simulation approaches applicable to the maintenance event.

Screenshot of the Simulation feature showing the possible simulations for the event

After selecting one of the possible simulations, a detailed view is available.

Screenshot of the Simulation feautre showing the simulation of nZDM

The Cutover Plan feature provides a template cutover plan based on the runtimes reported by the Software Update Manager. You can adapt the timings and export the plan for use in planning runs on the next systems.

Screenshot of the CutoverPlan feature showing the timeline view

What’s next?

Check it out and CLICK HERE!

We’re constantly making improvements to the Technical Downtime Optimization app. Our dedication to innovation means that the screenshots you see today may already be outdated, as we are continuously introducing newer, more intuitive features. Your feedback is crucial to this ongoing process, so please don't hesitate to use the Feedback button to share your thoughts with us.

Thank you for helping us make our app even better!

entry.title: DMOVE2S4 – your one-step approach into the cloud
entry.content:
Highlights

DMOVE2S4 is a one-step solution provided by Software Update Manager that integrates the transition to the cloud with system maintenance. It supports products that are built on SAP S/4HANA and requires a strong and stable network for data transfer. 

 

Introducing DMOVE2S4

With Software Update Manager 2.0, SAP offers the swiss army knife for maintenance scenarios. It supports operating system and database migrations, software updates and upgrades, system conversions to SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud Edition, as well as downtime-optimization scenarios for these tasks. 

Database Migration Option to SAP S/4HANA (on hyperscaler), short DMOVE2S4, is an offering by Software Update Manager for the seamless transition to RISE with SAP, combining the move from on-premise to the cloud with either a system conversion from SAP ERP 6.0 to SAP S/4HANA or an update/upgrade of SAP S/4HANA as the following picture illustrates.

And the best part? DMOVE2S4 is built on the proven mechanisms of Software Update Manager, ensuring a smooth and reliable journey into the cloud. Those who are familiar with DMO know, that there are two approaches which differ (not only) in their means of data transfer: 

  • DMO – transfers data based on memory pipes 
  • DMO with System Move (⚠️ not to be confused with DMOVE2S4) – transfers data based on data files 

For DMOVE2S4, the approach Database Migration Option (DMO) with system maintenance (either system conversion or upgrade) is combined with the move to a hyperscaler. Sounds simple but offers amazing results: You can do your move to the cloud in one step with the system maintenance and are ready to go. This also means, that DMOVE2S4 is not a separate selection in the Software Update Manager User Interface. On top, DMOVE2S4 can be combined with downtime-optimized DMO as well as downtime-optimized Conversion. It is worth mentioning that the DMOVE2S4 approach can also be used for moving to the cloud even without updating or upgrading your SAP S/4HANA system, although other transfer methods such as tenant copy of SAP HANA may be more suitable in such cases.

To benefit from DMOVE2S4 following prerequisites must be considered: 

  • Only target products based on SAP S/4HANA and SAP S/4HANA Foundation are supported. 
  • The Network connection must be sufficient*.

*Please refer to the latest DMO Guide for details.

If the prerequisites cannot be met, Software Update Manager also got your back with DMO with System Move. The approach also allows for a smooth transition to the cloud; however, it cannot be combined with downtime-optimization approaches such as downtime-optimized DMO or downtime-optimized Conversion. 

For further information please refer to the following links: 

DMO Guide: DMO Move to SAP S/4HANA (on Hyperscaler) | SAP Help Portal 

SAP Note: 3431829 - Database Migration Option (DMO) of SUM 2.0 SP20, section g) 

SAP HANA Guide: Copying and Moving Tenant Databases (without software change)

 

Questions? Feedback? Concerns? Comment below and let us know!

entry.title: What's new in DTV 1.5
entry.content:
It’s a been a while since DTV 1.5 is released, and I am more than happy to share more information regarding the latest release of Data Transition Validation Tool, DTV 1.5.

Partial Execution

In DTV 1.5 partial execution of data simulation, extraction and evaluation is now enabled in work item level. In a real time, scenario, when we define multiple split parameters for greater granularity of data, execution of huge amount of data may lead to failures sometimes. With partial execution enablement, now

users can execute simulation, extraction, and evaluation of individual failed work items instead of the whole test specification saving valuable time during business data evaluation in business down time.

Specify Maximum number of work processes

Whether it is Simulation, Extraction or Evaluation, DTV creates background jobs for processing and executing work items. For optimum system performance, now you can define dedicated number of work processes which can be utilized for DTV for background jobs, further finetuning the DTV overall performance.

You can do the setup in Maintain Systems -> Max. num of Processes.

Result Data

The entire result data of the reports including the hidden fields can now be seen in the Result Data making the analysis easy and intuitive for the end user.

Copy the project including the Test Specification

In DTV 1.5 you have the possibility to copy the project global data and the test specifications to further improve the usability of the tool.

 

Execution Runtime information is enhanced with delay time calculations

In DTV 1.5, overall execution time is calculated by including the delay time (execution time + delay time). The delay time is nothing but the time a job waits to get a free work process. This gives the end user an opportunity to improve the execution by providing optimum number of work processes and increasing the hardware if necessary.

entry.title: From History to Innovation: Analyzing Custom SAP System Evolution - A Primer
entry.content:
A Glimpse into the History of Custom SAP Systems

Consider the transport history of a small to medium-sized enterprise (SME). This record captures essential moments in the system's life - when transports occurred, who approved them, and which objects were moved into production. Such insights provide a clear picture of how the system has developed over time.

Example of ERP system workbench transport history (SME customer)Example of ERP system customizing transport history (same SME customer)

The volume of transported objects varies with company size. Larger enterprises often show a higher density of daily transports, reflecting more extensive system usage:

Another customer example of an SAP ECC workbench transport history. The blue hatched area represents the density of the daily transports as additional information 

It becomes more interesting when we take the transport history of a software package (DEVLASS) as an example for this customer and plot the individual developers and their activities:

An example software package (DEVLASS) workbench transport history of this customer

Each horizontal line represents the activity of a user within the software package (DEVLASS). The names of the users are grayed out for privacy reasons)

When looking at the activities based on the workbench transport history and considering the time-limited activities of users along with their simultaneous or staggered actions, we can discuss the development history and the developers involved. This makes for a good conversation starter with the relevant development manager, system administrator, or subject matter expert: "Which developer is the most experienced?", "Was knowledge able to be passed on between developers?", "Can I identify development initiatives?", "These two developers are our best procurement process experts!"

The way this information is presented is well-suited for storytelling.

 

Storytelling and Reconstructed History

Storytelling transforms complex technical processes into relatable narratives. Instead of drowning stakeholders in dry details, the narrative approach fosters collaboration between IT teams and business stakeholders. When technical information is presented as a story, IT professionals can communicate their ideas more effectively, leading to richer discussions about system features and enhancements.

However, storytelling comes with its challenges. One risk is exaggeration or misrepresentation; presenting hypothetical scenarios as facts can create misunderstandings and unrealistic expectations. To maintain trust, it’s crucial that stories are grounded in real data.

 

Understanding the Evolution of Custom SAP Systems for Better Transformation

Every custom SAP system tells a story shaped by organizational decisions throughout its development. This narrative encompasses not just technical specifications but also the experiences of those involved. Analyzing this evolution helps organizations make informed decisions about their software strategies.

Having spent years in Custom Development and Innovative Business Solutions (IBSO), I’ve seen firsthand how important it is to examine software evolution. The method of Software Evolution Analysis arose from the need for quick communication with clients about custom systems. This analysis captures the essence of a system's history, showing how past choices influence current functions and future developments.

In future blog posts, I will go deeper into this topic, sharing examples and insights that demonstrate how storytelling can clarify the complexities of custom SAP systems. Additionally, I will showcase analyses and modeling techniques that further enhance our understanding of these systems.

 

References

  1. Change and Transport System (CTS): https://support.sap.com/en/tools/software-logistics-tools/change-and-transport-system.html 
  2. Lehman, M. M., & Belady, L. (1974). "Program Evolution: Processes of Software Change."  (remark: The article by Lehman was published in 1974, just two years after the founding of SAP in 1972 by former IBM employees.); Lehman, M. M. (1980). "Programs, Life Cycles, and the Laws of Software Evolution." In Proceedings of the IEEE.
  3. Story telling as a term concerning software: Domain Storytelling is a collaborative modeling technique that brings together domain experts and development teams to visualize and narrate business processes, making domain knowledge transparent and actionable for software development (domainstorytelling.org, Quick-Start Guide, Book by Hofer & Schwentner). User Stories in agile development are concise, narrative requirements from the user's perspective, supporting iterative planning and user-centered design (domainstorytelling.org/domain-driven-design). Storytelling is also crucial in software introduction, as it helps communicate changes and benefits, motivates users, and eases adoption by embedding new systems in relatable narratives (gotopia.tech: The Power of Domain Storytelling).
  4. Story telling and it's meaning from different aspects: Jerome Bruner’s influential book, Acts of Meaning (1990), explores how storytelling is fundamental to human sense-making and cultural understanding; the book is available through resources such as MIT’s PDF archive and the Internet Archive. In the field of evolutionary biology, Stephen Jay Gould and Richard C. Lewontin’s seminal article, “The Spandrels of San Marco and the Panglossian Paradigm: A Critique of the Adaptationist Programme” (Proceedings of the Royal Society of London. Series B, Biological Sciences, 1979), critically examines adaptationist storytelling in evolutionary theory and can be accessed via JSTOR.

Keeping SAP systems updated and secure is essential. The "View Recommended Notes" feature in Maintenance Planner provides a tailored list of SAP Notes based on the system's current status, helping ensure systems stay up-to-date, secure, and compliant with evolving business and legal requirements.

Intelligent Ranking for Prioritizing SAP Notes

Ranking helps in identifying and prioritizing the most relevant SAP Notes likely to be applicable to your system. This ranking is determined by artificial intelligence, based on the SAP Notes already implemented within your system.

The criteria for ranking include:

  • ABAP Dictionary Object: Notes involving modifications to the same ABAP Dictionary objects as the implemented notes.
  • Prerequisites: Notes with prerequisites that reference already implemented notes.
  • System Similarity: Notes that are implemented in similar systems.

The ranking results for recommended SAP Notes are dynamic and continuously recalculated based on new or updated SAP Notes and system changes.

entry.title: Enablement of partial or work item level execution in DTV tool
entry.content:
Problem Statement

If you are already using DTV tool for business data validation, you may already know that DTV generates work items as per the split parameters provided in the test specifications.

Customers may sometimes get to a scenario where they wish to.

  • Execute individual or set of work items of their choice
  • Execute failed/ cancelled work items only

To address such requirements DTV tool introduces partial execution or work item level execution in the new release DTV 1.5. With this concept Execution of extraction, evaluation and simulation are possible not only at the test specification, but also at the individual split (Work items).

Work Items

With DTV 1.5 release onwards, the tool is introduced with new concept called work item level execution. For each Extraction/Simulation, the tool generates work items explicitly first and then the work item level execution happens for respective work items. In this way DTV facilitates smaller data extraction as well as if extraction for one or more work item fails/cancels, you can run the failed/cancelled work items explicitly which makes the overall DTV execution faster.

You can find the Generate Workitems buttons in both Simulation as well as Extraction screens as highlighted below.

You can see the generated work items in the Result tab.

Project Global Data and Work Items

In DTV project global data is used to split the business data into smaller chunks and the project global data is also applicable to all the reports. But it is worth to mention that the definition of project global data is directly related to number of work items that will be generated during the Extraction / Simulation phase.

In the below example of project global data, only one work item will be created.

However, it is always recommended to further split the project global data to generate multiple work items for smaller and faster simulation/extraction. Below is a simple example of further finetuning of the project global data.

Once work items are generated you can execute the work items with different options as per your requirement

Select multiple work items and run

operating system users. Only the <sapsid>adm user needs access to this subdirectory. In addition, you should not share this subdirectory in the network. If you save the SUM directory for later analysis After the update has finished, delete the file MEMSAPup.dat.
ddic credentials are needed for the RFC connection to the SAP system. To be able to perform all necessary actions, the user DDIC needs the authorization SAP_ALL.

Usually, it is not necessary to change the password of the user DDIC during the upgrade. If you do change
the password, you have to change it in the original system, the shadow system, and in the Software Update Manager.

#################################Configuration- Phase##############################

Select the radio option for "No disabling of the database archive mode."

ABAP Processes (Uptime & Downtime):

This parameter determines the number of processes used in job phases. It affects all job-run phases, including long runtime ones such as DBCLONE (in update situations), ACT_UPG and PARDIST in uptime, and XPRAs in downtime.

The DBCLONE phase has a technical restriction of 10 parallel processes at most, therefore increasing the number would not assist.

SQL Processes (Uptime & Downtime):

This option specifies the number of parallel SQL statements to be executed on the database at the same time. This setting is especially beneficial for the DDL (data definition language) phases, such as MVNTAB and PARCONV, where commands like "create table," "alter table," "create index," and others are executed. This parameter is also used by the phases that construct aliases/synonyms for the shadow system (SCEXEC_GRANT + SCEXEC_ALIAS), albeit to a lesser extent. The recommended value is the total number of physical CPUs.

R3trans Processes (Uptime & Downtime):

This parameter is used for tp and R3trans transport tools in parallel during the phases where support packages are imported (DDIC_UPG, SHADOW_IMPORT*, and TABIM_UPG).

Recommended value is 1 to 2 times the CPU, with a maximum of 50 CPUs.

If your CPU is multi-core, the SAP system will treat it as a physical, available CPU.
For example, if you have four quad-core CPUs, the SAP system will recognize them as sixteen CPUs in ST06. In this situation, you can put '16' for both the UPTIME and DOWNTIME R3TRANS PROCESSES fields (note that standard transport requests import may still occur during uptime, and they share the same tp/R3trans resources). So, avoid importing requests during upgrades.

R3load Processes (Uptime & Downtime):

This parameter guides the upgrade tool how many R3load processes will be executed during phases EU_IMPORT* (in system releases upgrade) and DMO (data migration option) scenarios to transfer data from the old database to the new HANA one. Because R3load uses modest CPU processing, you can safely specify a large value for this parameter: 3 to 5 times the number of CPUs.

In our case, select the radio button HOSTNAME_SID_<nn>

SAP Load Generator (SGEN) is a transaction that compiles ABAP repository objects that are newly supplied into the system, either through an installation or an upgrade/support package import. The term "Load" refers to an ABAP runtime object used in ABAP settings.
The ABAP objects are stored on their source code in table REPOSRC and on their runtime state in table REPOLOAD.

If you selected the Advanced pre-configuration mode in SUM, you would get the following prompt

Choose an execution strategy for transaction SGEN.

  • Do not start ABAP load generation during the update

If you plan to apply a high number of relevant changes to your system in the form of SPS updates or upgrades. We recommend that you generate the ABAP loads manually at end of post-processing phase.

  • Generate ABAP loads on shadow system during uptime.

With this option, the Software Update Manager uses the maximum number of processes entered below to generate the loads in the shadow instance during the uptime in the update phase SUBMOD_SHD2_RUN/RUN_RSGEN.

Usually, the shadow SGEN prolongs the uptime part of the update procedure or several hours. If you run into unexpected time issues with your update schedule and you want to save the SGEN time, you can abort a running shadow SGEN by executing the report RSUPG_SGEN_ABORT_SHADOW in the shadow system. Use the DDIC user for the logon. Note that as soon as the SUM run is completed, you have to perform a manual SGEN run to generate the missing loads.

  • Generate ABAP loads on shadow system during uptime and start asynchronously in post downtime.

With this option, the Software Update Manager uses the maximum number of processes entered below to generate the ABAP loads in the shadow instance during the uptime in the update phase SUBMOD_SHD2_RUN/RUN_RSGEN

The transaction SGEN automatically starts again after the downtime during the Postprocessing roadmap step to regenerate the ABAP loads that were invalidated during the downtime in phase MAIN_POSTP/RUN_RSREGENLOD

DB Clone Phase:

During this phase, the target system (shadow system) is copied from the current system. The Software Update Manager initiates background processes to copy the necessary tables for the shadow system's operation.

Depending on your system and your hardware, this operation can take several hours. These background jobs are executed on the background server that is configured with the BATCH HOST parameter. The number of jobs is determined by the parameter MAX BATCH PROCESSES. It cannot be higher than nine or the number of background processes configured on the background server.
Each table is copied with a single INSERT statement. Therefore, the administrator has to take care that the undo-logs can grow accordingly.

Each cloning job writes a log file called DBCLONE<NUMBER>.<SID>.
At the end of the phase, all errors found in these log files are collected in the DBCLONE.ELG file.
The information in the DBCLONE.ELG file is rather sparse. Therefore, you also have to check the corresponding log files to find detailed information about the error.

2. Add an entry for the shadow instance to the SAP Logon. For the server and system ID, use the values from the original system

################################Postprocessing- Phase################################

Downtime:

The time during which you cannot use the system productively.
The upgrade strategy determines when downtime begins during an upgrade.

The duration of the downtime depends on several factors, including:
• Hardware

Business downtime:  The total time during which the SAP system is not available to end users.

Technical downtime:  The time during which the SAP system is not available due to processing routines in the system launched by the SUM tool.

SUM technical downtime: The time during which the system is not available due to processing during the
SUM runs.

UPGANA File: The report generated upon successful execution additionally contains the time statistics of the performed update, for example, the calculated SUM technical downtime value.

This file will be very useful for taking downtime approval and addressing issues in each phase for the sub-sequent systems in the landscape.

entry.title: Simplify the downtime-optimized System Conversion to SAP S/4HANA with Uptime Customizing for FI
entry.content:
---

TL;DR 

Software Update Manager’s downtime-optimized conversion approach significantly reduces downtime during a system conversion to SAP S/4HANA. This approach is now significantly improved, resulting in fewer conversion cycles which means reducing the overall project runtime.

The key idea here is making the required Customizing settings on a temporary instance. This approach allows you to adjust the required Customizing settings during a downtime-optimized conversion run, therefore eliminating the need for additional standard conversion cycles. 

---

 

If you want to convert your system to SAP S/4HANA (also sometime referred to as brownfield approach), you're talking Software Update Manager. This tool is well-known to SAP Basis and Technology folks as it is the standard tooling for SAP system maintenance.

Software Update Manager also covers the important conversion step from SAP ERP to SAP S/4HANA. If you’re familiar with system conversions, or are already in the planning phase, you know by now that it is NOT just another upgrade. It is not only a technical step to enable the system to consume latest technologies (AI is calling!), but also requires thorough preparation at application level. And in addition, using Software Update Manger for the conversion might result in a longer downtime than your business is willing to accept. 

 

Recap of downtime-optimized Conversion

But here's the amazing news: There is a downtime-optimized approach available with Software Update Manager that moves activities that normally require the business to be stopped, into an uptime window in which the Software Update Manager works in parallel to the ongoing business.

More information on this approach called downtime-optimized conversion is available here.

The magic of this approach, in addition to utilizing the capabilities of downtime-optimized Database Migration Option (DMO) - lies in moving data conversion activities to uptime. This even includes activities which normally have to be executed manually after the conversion with Software Update Manager is complete. This reduces downtime significantly. The image below illustrates the standard conversion, the block FIN (Finance) & ML (Material Ledger) Data Conversion represents the manual activities.

 

 With a downtime-optimized conversion, the process looks like this:

 

The big downside...

HOWEVER, there is one major challenge: To automate the manual FI&ML conversion activities, Software Update Manager requires information on what to do. To provide this information, a standard conversion run is required that also includes the manual FIN&ML conversion. This is typically done on a copy of the production system. The resulting Customizing settings are saved in a customer transport, which is then included in the next downtime-optimized Software Update Manager run.

Doesn't sound like a challenge? Well - that's true. But the Knackpunkt (excuse my German, crucial point simply doesn't sound dramatic enough 🤔) arises with time. As the initial standard conversion that runs on a copy of production and the actual production go-live are often some months apart, the Customizing on the production system very likely changes in the course of time.

And the result ⁉️

The content of the initial Customizing transport and the actual existing Customizing in the production system no longer match. If you were to run a downtime-optimized conversion using said Customizing transport Software Update Manager would apply the "old" Customizing, overwriting any changes on production that are not reflected in the customer transport.

Obviously, one solution is to copy production again to a sandbox system, complete a standard conversion run and afterwards manually execute the FI&ML conversion activities which result in a new, updated Customizing transport.

☹️This basically means, that any downtime-optimized conversion cycle (e.g. sandbox, load verification, dress rehearsal, go-live) needs a preceding standard conversion run - which massively bloats the project plan. This is a major drawback of the approach as it leads to a longer project runtime and therefore introduces complexity to the planning.

Well, I should say this has been a major drawback...

 

... mitigated with Uptime Customizing for FI Conversion

As the downtime-optimized conversion approach is constantly evolving it also covers a solution for the outdated Customizing issue. With Uptime Customizing for FI Conversion on the Temporary Instance, Software Update Manager offers the possibility to adapt the respective Customizing during the downtime-optimized conversion run itself - eliminating the need for an additional standard cycle. Note that the first standard conversion cycle is still required.

The following screenshot of Software Update Manager shows the dialog where you confirm that the relevant Customizing activities are complete (version 2.0 SP23 PL0):

In this phase, your application experts can log on to the temporary instance (which "reuses" of the shadow instance). The temporary instance exists on the same host with the same SID as the original instance but has a different instance number (the shadow instance number chosen in an earlier Software Update Manager dialog).

Once the Customizing settings have been adjusted, the downtime-optimized conversion run continues. These Customizing settings are saved in a transport which can then be added to the list of customer transports that are provided to the Software Update Manager in the upcoming downtime-optimized conversion cycles - ensuring that the latest changes are reflected. 

 

Additional Resources

To get started with your transition to SAP S/4HANA with this optimized flavor of the system conversion, here's a collection of information:

  • Support Portal Page of Software Update Manager: https://support.sap.com/en/tools/software-logistics-tools/software-update-manager.html
  • Support Portal Page of downtime-optimized conversion approach of Software Update Manager: https://support.sap.com/en/tools/software-logistics-tools/software-update-manager/downtime-optimized-conversion-approach.html
  • Guide for downtime-optimized Conversion with Software Update Manager: https://help.sap.com/docs/help/c4ebc2b5d928446180d9ad2667f11faa/c603616d71104e36a48330be959ed8dc.html?locale=en-US 
  • Additional information on Uptime Customizing for FI Conversion: SAP Note 3444013

Let us know what you think and feel free to comment below!

For any technical issues, please open an SAP case on component BC-UPG-DTM-TLA.

All the best for your project!
